docs.title: Supercharge Your LLMs with Personal Data Using Model Context Protocol
docs.text:
Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open protocol that standardizes how applications provide context to LLMs. It was originally created by Anthropic and released in late 2024. MCP protocol allows an application (MCP Host) to connect to multiple MCP Servers that expose specific capabilities through the standardized protocol.

MCP Architecture Overview

Over the last few months multiple vendor and open source projects have started to implement MCP in their products. That includes popular development tools like Cursor, Windsurf, and Cline. Open source community embraced MCP and started to build MCP servers catalogue. MCP was a hot topic at the 2025 AI Engineer Summit in New York City with several presentations and workshops covering this topic.

docs.title: Getting started with MCP
docs.text: Anthropic has created a set of SDKs and tools to help developers easily integrate MCP in their applications. MCP SDKs.

docs.title: Connecting with your personal data
docs.text:
For the last several month I have been using Garmin Venu 3 watch to track my fitness activities and sleep. Venu 3 tracks heart rate, steps, and sleep, activities, and other metrics. Garmin Connect is the platform that syncs data from the watch to the cloud and allows to view it. It also provides an API to access and download your data. python-garminconnect is a Python wrapper to access Garmin Connect API.

Source code for this blog post is available here. To get started, clone the repository and install the required dependencies:

git clone https://github.com/dshvadskiy/garmin_mcp.git
cd garmin_mcp
uv sync

After obtaining your Garmin Connect API token, MCP server implementation is straightforward.

from mcp.server.fastmcp import FastMCP

api = init_api(email, password)

# Create an MCP server
mcp = FastMCP("Garmin Connect MCP Server")

@mcp.tool()
def fetch_sleep_data(date: str) -> dict:
    """Returns sleep data for a given date
    Args:
        date: str - date in format YYYY-MM-DD
    Returns:
        dict - sleep data
    """
    return api.get_sleep_data(date)

@mcp.tool()
def fetch_heart_rate_data(date: str) -> dict:
    """Returns heart rate data for a given date
    Args:
        date: str - date in format YYYY-MM-DD
    Returns:
        dict - heart rate data
    """
    return api.get_rhr_day(date)

Test your server using MCP Inspector: 

mcp dev garmin_mcp_server.py

MCP Inspector

Register with Claude Desktop: 

mcp install garmin_mcp_server.py

After restarting Claude Desktop, your MCP server appears in the Installed MCP servers list:

MCP Server in Claude Desktop

Now let's ask Claude to analyze my fitness data and recommend appropriate activities based on my personal metrics.

MCP Server Authorization

Claude Desktop makes several calls to fetch activities, stress, and heart rate data and generates some suggestions.

AI-Generated Exercise Recommendations

We've successfully linked personal fitness data to an LLM with just a few lines of code. This connection enables AI to deliver personalized insights based on your unique information.
